awd_titl_txt: Thriving Through Relationships: A Longitudinal Investigation of Support for Thriving Over a Decade of Marriage
awd_abstract_narration:
Close and caring relationships are undeniably linked to health and well-being at all stages in the lifespan. Yet the specific pathways through which close relationships promote optimal well-being and thriving are not well understood. This project offers an integrative theoretical model describing interpersonal processes that influence human thriving. The goal of this project is to test a model of social support and thriving developed from an integration of three literatures - the positive well-being literature, the social support literature, and the close relationships literature. This model highlights two life contexts through which people may potentially thrive, it proposes two relational support functions that promote thriving in each life context, and it identifies mechanisms through which relational support is likely to have long-term effects on thriving. The model is tested by examining close relationship processes over time in couples who have been married for over a decade. This perspective can help us understand how social support may be a critical interpersonal process that contributes to couples' thriving, and also to individual well-being.

This project examines an integrative model of social support as an interpersonal process that influences thriving. Couples (N = 160) who were newly married in 2005/2006 will again be investigated as they enter their 11th year of marriage. A longitudinal data collection includes surveys with the aim of predicting long-term thriving from observations and surveys obtained in the first years of marriage. The data collection also includes an observational and physiological session to examine the effects of relational support functions on mechanisms that drive long-term thriving outcomes, including physiological mechanisms. The data collection also includes a daily diary component to examine the effects of relational support functions on proximal outcomes. Lastly, in the 12th year of marriage, couples will complete follow-up assessments of thriving with the aim of prospectively predicting thriving from the interpersonal processes assessed in the 11th year of marriage. This project provides a foundation for understanding interpersonal processes and their role in thriving, and the development of relationship-based interventions aimed at promoting public health. This is especially important because social support is a major contributor to well-being and mental health in the U.S. and across the world.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of this research identify specific relationship processes that have implications for human thriving. This project tests a model of social support and thriving that highlights two life contexts through which people may potentially thrive (adversity and life opportunity), it establishes two relational support functions that promote thriving in each life context, and it identifies mechanisms through which relational support has long-term effects on thriving. 

Methodological outcomes include rigorous longitudinal methods that yielded a rare, multi-method longitudinal dataset with a sample of couples and individuals who have been followed for over a decade (in the current investigation and over a decade prior when newlyweds in the original NSF funded project). The rich dataset that emerged from this work includes couples’ longitudinal survey data, video-recordings of couple interactions, couples’ daily diary data, and couples’ physiological data that spans a period of over 10 years given the original investigation on which this project built. The video-recordings have been extensively coded for both primary and secondary data analysis.

Data analysis for this large dataset and preparation of empirical reports are still in progress. Publications that have emerged from this project thus far have shown the following: In one publication of this work with the daily diary data, we found that affectionate touch (a supportive behavior that is a prime target for intervention) encourages couple members to prioritize other shared positive activities and to view shared couple activities more positively. Using the diary data, we found that greater affectionate touch on one day predicted increases in couples’ shared positive activities concurrently and prospectively. These results suggest that affectionate touch (as a supportive behavior) may facilitate positive relationship experiences broadly, and results support our theoretical model of ways that individuals might thrive through relationships.

In another published manuscript, given the benefits of supportive touch, we examined individual differences in desire for affectionate touch. Results indicated that the strongest predictors of overall desire for touch were sex (being female) and high relationship quality. Although attachment avoidance predicted lower desire for affectionate touch, greater psychological distress predicted greater desire for affectionate touch (indicating that touch is especially welcome and beneficial in times of adversity). This information about desire for affectionate touch provides a foundation for future intervention work that seeks to increase it for positive couple and individual outcomes.

Another published manuscript from this project, using the daily diary data, examined links between relationship factors and sleep quality (an important health behavior). Using Actor–Partner Interdependence Models, we tested and found direct links between attachment orientation and sleep quality. Moreover, we found that these direct effects were explained by feelings of security within the relationship and by negative emotion. For example, couple members with an insecure attachment orientation had poorer sleep quality because they feel less secure with their specific partner and because they experience more negative emotion.

Additional data analyses and research reports are in progress, given the large nature of the dataset and given that we recently completed coding of the video-recorded interactions. Regarding broader impacts, this work has the potential to guide future research on relational impacts on human thriving. It highlights the importance of considering the impact of specific social behaviors that are enacted in dyadic interaction, and it puts the spotlight on close relationships as being central to facilitating or hindering multiple domains of human thriving. The dataset can be used by other scientists for various secondary purposes, and the outcomes of this project will be useful in developing and testing theory-based and research-based interventions for enhancing relational support and thriving outcomes. This project will provide a foundation for the development of relationship-based interventions aimed at promoting public health. This is especially important given that the United Nations’ World Happiness Report, which was offered as a contribution to the policy debate regarding the world’s Sustainable Development Goals for the period 2015-2030, identified social support as one of the main contributors to the world’s mental health.

 


Last Modified: 06/01/2023
Modified by: Brooke C Feeney
